content.text: Questions 41-45 are based on the following text:
content.name: fbJP

content.text: Graffiti has often been associated with urban rebellion and self-expression. Nevertheless, it has a rich and multifaceted history. Its origins trace back to ancient civilizations, where individuals carved symbols and messages on cave walls and structures. In modern times, graffiti emerged as an urban art form in the 20th century,
content.name: sGL0

content.text: particularly in the streets of New York City.
content.name: 227S

content.text: The 1970s marked a significant turning point when graffiti evolved into a distinct subculture. Young artists, or "writers," adorned subway cars and building facades with vibrant murals and tags, creating an underground movement. This artistic rebellion gained recognition and influence worldwide.
content.name: zI8O

content.text: Graffiti's impact on contemporary art cannot be overstated. Renowned artists drew inspiration from its vibrant aesthetics. Today, graffiti has transcended its rebellious origins, with street art festivals and mural projects celebrating its contribution to urban culture.
content.name: IDv6

content.text: Graffiti's history is a testament to the power of art and self-expression, reminding us that creativity can flourish even in the most unexpected places.
content.name: K5F8
2I2y

content.text: Questions 46-50 are based on the following text:
content.name: dRI0

content.text: When it comes to culinary adventures, there are some foods around the world that might make you raise an eyebrow or even cringe. From insects to fermented delicacies, here are some of the weirdest foods that have found a place on global plates.
content.name: Nwer

content.text: Balut (Philippines): In the Philippines, balut is a popular street food. It's a fertilized duck embryo boiled and eaten directly from the shell. While it might sound unusual, it's considered a delicacy with a unique flavor.
content.name: uoCa

content.text: Hákarl (Iceland): Hákarl is fermented shark meat, a traditional Icelandic dish. It's buried underground for several months, then hung to dry for several more. The result is an acquired taste due to its strong ammonia smell.
content.name: K4Zb

content.text: Escamoles (Mexico):Escamoles are ant larvae, often referred to as "insect caviar." These tiny, nutty-tasting larvae are a delicacy in Mexico, usually served in tacos or omelets.
content.name: JoWl

content.text: Stink Cheese (Sweden):Known as "surströmming," this Swedish delicacy is fermented herring. The strong smell can be off-putting, but its taste is surprisingly mild, often enjoyed with potatoes and onions.
content.name: rjSL

content.text: Century Egg (China): Century eggs are preserved for several weeks or months, resulting in a translucent, dark-colored egg. Despite their strong smell, they have a creamy yolk with a unique flavor.
content.name: p2qx

content.text: Natto (Japan): Natto is fermented soybeans with a strong, pungent odor and a slimy texture. It's often eaten with rice for breakfast in Japan.
content.name: SKhk

content.text: These are just a few examples of the diverse and unusual foods found around the world.
content.name: g2qV
QCIa

Discussing the health benefits of strange foods.

Describing unusual and exotic foods from different cultures.

Escamoles.

It has a strong flavor. 
It has a strong smell.
b

Pungent odor and slimy texture.
Popularity as a breakfast dish.
Unique flavor due to fermentation.
c
